The utilization of Cu-based catalysts in the low-temperature catalytic conversion of CO2 to methanol is the focus of industrial processes. However, the metastable nature of highly dispersed Cu active sites causes it easy to sinter, which leads to the decline of activity and methanol selectivity. Herein, an approach involving the incorporation of highly dispersed La species into Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 (CZAL-x) through one-pot synthesis, benefits dispersing and stabilizing Cu0/Cu+ active sites. Consequently, a CO2 conversion reaches 22.4 % with a 75.0 % methanol selectivity of the optimizing CZAL-2.5 catalyst in a stable reaction for 100 h. When the space velocity is 16,000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, the space-time yield of methanol reached the highest value of 814.9 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1, significantly outperforming the CZA catalyst. Systematic characterizations reveal the introduction of LaOx enhanced the interaction between Cu active sites and carrier, which effectively improved the sintering resistance of copper nanoparticles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Table of contents Constructing a stable and highly active CZAL-2.5 catalyst modulating by highly dispersed LaOx species for catalytic conversion of CO2 to methanol. Keywords Robust Cu active sites Highly dispersed LaOx CO2 hydrogenation reaction Methanol selectivity Anti-sintering Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 is an overlooked carbon resource that can be transformed into high-value-added products, like methanol, ethanol, gasoline, aviation fuel, and aromatic hydrocarbons through hydrogenation reactions [1–10]. Among these, the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol reaction stands out. This is attributed to the process yielding a singular product at a low separation cost, with methanol being a crucial chemical feedstock extensively utilized in industries such as methanol fuel cells, the production of lower olefins and hydrogen, etc. [2–5]. A wide scope of metal/oxide catalysts have been developed for the CO2-to-methanol transformation, such as the oxide catalyst of ZnZrOx [11–12], InOx [13–14], and supported metal nanoparticle catalysts containing Cu, Pd, Rh, Co, Ni [15–20]. Among these catalysts, Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 catalysts are among the most traditional tools for the hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol, finding extensive usage in academic and industrial settings alike. One major challenge with these catalysts is that the active metallic copper nanoparticles tend to sinter during the reaction process because of their low Tamman temperature at 407 °C. Aggregation of copper nanoparticles results in lowered catalytic activity. The precarious balance between activity and selectivity often leads to suboptimal catalytic performance, with an increase in activity leading to a decrease in catalyst selectivity [21]. Over the past decade, significant efforts have been derived to modulate Cu-based catalysts by utilizing promoters like ZrO2, SiO2, MnOx, CeO2, La2O3, etc., to geometrically and/or electronically modulate the active Cu species [22–26]. For instance, Wang and co-workers introduced SiOx species onto CuZnAl catalysts. Despite successfully improving methanol selectivity and catalytic stability, the resultant activity was dramatically inhibited, dropping from 23.4 % to 12.6 %. Furthermore, although the use of a hydrophobic promoter to regulate the copper catalyst has enhanced activity and stability in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the methanol selectivity dipped sharply from 61.3 % to 46.5 % [25]. Nie and his co-workers prepared CuO/LayCeOx catalysts with La doping. They found that the CuO/La0.25CeOx catalyst, with a La molar fraction of 25 %, exhibited excellent catalytic performance with a methanol space-time yield of 0.281 g/(g·h) and a methanol selectivity of 83.3 %. This was attributed to the formation of LaCeOx solid solutions in CuO/LayCeOx due to La doping, which enhanced the metal-support interaction [27]. Researchers have proposed using encapsulated copper catalysts by zeolite or organic frameworks to trigger the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [28–31]. For example, the Lin group designed a Cu-based catalyst with Cu/ZnOx nanoparticles confined in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which achieved high methanol selectivity and catalytic stability with a CO2 conversion of 3.3 % [31]. Herein, a strategy of the incorporation of La species into Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 (CZAL-x, x at% is La/Cu atomic ratio) through one-pot synthesis is advanced to enhance the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity. Systemic studies of the structural-activity relationship reveal that the introduced LaOx could not only promote the dispersion of Cu active sites but also benefit the improvement of the structural robustness of Cu nanoparticles. Also, the moderate basic sites are in favor of the adsorption of CO2. Importantly, the addition of LaOx species would form more Cuδ+ species (Cu-LaOx) rather than Cu0 species, which rationally contributed to the prevention of catalyst deactivation and against to form CO, thus boosting the methanol STY. As a result, La-doped CZA catalysts, show obvious improvements in activity and stability. This work yields new insights into the synthesis of robust and highly dispersed Cu-based catalysts applied in the CO2 hydrogenation field. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Experimental materials Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 98.0 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 98.0 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, 98.0 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3 6H2O, 99.99 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), and sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, 99.5 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Cu-ZnO-Al2O3-LaOx (CZAL) catalysts with different La loadings were prepared by co-precipitation method with atomic ratios of Cu/Zn/Al at 50/35/15, and the atomic ratios of La/Cu at 1 at%, 2.5 at%, 5 at%, 10 at%, and 20 at%, respectively. As a typical run for the synthesis of CZAL-1 catalyst with an atomic ratio of La/Cu at 1 at%, 2.41 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 2.079 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, and 1.125 g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.043 g of La(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 500 mL distilled water under stirring. The obtained solution was introduced into a beaker under vigorous stirring at room temperature together with Na2CO3 solution (1 M). The pH value of the mixture was maintained at ∼8.5. After that, the precipitates were aged at room temperature for 24 h followed by filtrating and washing with a large amount of water to remove the resident Na+ from the precipitate. This precipitate was then dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain the CZAL-1 sample. The CZAL-x samples with different La loadings with atomic ratios of La/Cu at 2.5 at%, 5 at%, 10 at%, and 20 at% were synthesized following the same procedures except using 0.108, 0.217, 0.433 and 0.866 g of La(NO3)3·6H2O in the starting solution and detailed element composition was detected by ICP-OES (Tables S1 and S2). 2.3 Characterization The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were obtained from a JEM-3100F microscope operating at 200 KV. The field emission scanning electron microscopic (FE-SEM) images were obtained from SU8220. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were determined with a Smart-Lab diffractometer with a radiation source of Cu Kα with a scanning rate of 1 ° min−1 in the range of 10∼90° at 40 KV and 30 mA. The texture properties of the fresh catalysts were determined by N2 physical sorption using Micromeritics 3Flex specific surface area and porous physical adsorption analyzer. Before the measurement, all samples were pretreated at 200 °C under vacuum for 12 h to remove the surface contaminants. The temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPD) tests were performed on AMI 300 apparatus equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The catalysts were pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h followed by cooling to 100 °C in Ar flow at 25 mL min−1. The temperature was then raised to 600 °C with a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1 under 10 vol% H2/Ar flow of 30 mL/min, and the consumed H2 was detected by TCD. The compositions of the catalysts were detected by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis (ICAP 7600). N2O temperature-programmed desorption (N2O-TPR) tests were detected on BELCAT-B apparatus equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The catalysts were pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h followed by cooling to 100 °C in Ar flow at 25 mL min−1. The temperature was then raised to 600 °C with a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1 under 10 vol% H2/Ar flow of 30 mL min−1, and the consumed H2 was detected by TCD. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption CO2-TPD was performed on the BELCAT-B apparatus equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C under 10 vol% H2/Ar flow of 30 mL min−1, followed by cooling to 60 °C in CO2 flow at 25 mL min−1 for 60 min. The temperature was then raised to 600 °C with a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1 under an Ar flow of 30 mL min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray Photoelectron Spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Kα source at 12 kV and 6 mA. CO2 adsorption by FTIR was detected by Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 apparatus with an MCT (Mercury Cadmium Telluride) detector in the range of 4000–650 cm−1. Thermogravimetry (TG) measurement was carried out using the spent catalysts in the air with a flow rate of 30 ml/min on a TG-GS/MS thermal analyzer (Netzsch). The program was performed at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 800 °C. 2.4 Catalyst test The catalytic CO2 hydrogenation was conducted in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. As a typical run, 0.5 g of as-prepared catalyst (20∼40 mesh) was mixed with 2.0 g of quartz sand (20∼40 mesh) and fixed in the middle of the reactor. The catalyst was pre-reduced in 10 vol% H2 flow (20 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 6 h, then the gas was switched to the mixture of CO2 and H2 (1:3) at a pressure of 1–7 MPa and temperature of 200∼300 °C to start the reaction. The gaseous products were analyzed by gas chromatographs (Aglient 7890) equipped with an activated carbon capillary column connected to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an HP-PLOT/Q capillary column connected to a flame ionization detector (FID). The carbon balance is maintained at 95 %∼105 %. The CO2 conversion, product selectivity, and the space-time yield (STY) of CH3OH were calculated according to the following formulas: (1) X ( C O 2 ) = ( n in ( C O 2 ) − n out ( C O 2 ) ) / n in ( C O 2 ) × 100 % (2) S ( CO ) = n out ( CO ) / ( n in ( C O 2 ) − n out ( C O 2 ) ) × 100 % (3) S ( MeOH ) = n out ( MeOH ) / ( n in ( C O 2 ) − n out ( C O 2 ) ) × 100 % (4) STY ( MeOH ) = m ( MeOH , g / h ) / m ( catalyst , kg ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Boosted and robust catalytic performance over lanthanum-modified CZAL-x catalysts A series of CZAL-x catalysts were assessed in a fixed-bed reactor under reaction conditions (1–7 MPa, 200–300 °C, 2000–16,000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, H2/CO2/Ar at 72/24/4, vol%). The results, including CO2 conversions, product selectivities, and space-time yield (STY), are summarized in Figs. 1 and S1 and S2. In contrast (Fig. 1a), the CZA catalyst demonstrated a low CO2 conversion of 13.1 % and a methanol selectivity of 75.1 %. The CZAL-1 catalyst exhibited a CO2 conversion of 16.8 % with a methanol selectivity of 76.6 %. Further, an increase in the lanthanum content simultaneously promoted the CO2 conversion of 18.1 % and methanol selectivity of 76.6 % in the CZAL-2.5 catalyst. However, the introduction of excess lanthanum led to a decline in CO2 conversions (15.3 %∼15.0 % for CZAL-5, CZAL-10, and CZAL-20). These results imply the positive impact of proper amounts of lanthanum compared with the conventional CZA catalyst. The optimized CZAL-2.5 catalyst was also tested at various space velocities ranging from 2000 to 16,000 mL gcat. −1 h−1 under mild reaction conditions (5.0 MPa, 260 °C, H2/CO2/Ar at 72/24/4, vol%). Fig. S1 summarizes the relationship between CO2 conversions, product selectivities, and methanol STY in the CZAL-2.5-catalyzed CO2 hydrogenation. The CZAL-2.5 catalyst achieved the highest CO2 conversion of 23.3 % at a space velocity of 2000 mL gcat. −1 h−1. Although the CO2 conversions slightly decreased with increasing space velocities, the methanol STY showed significant improvement. At space velocities of 4000 and 6000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, the methanol STY reached values of 250.0 and 361.9 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1 respectively. However, when the space velocity was further increased to 16,000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, the CO2 conversion gradually decreased to 20.0 % with a corresponding methanol selectivity of 71.9 %. In this case, the STY of methanol reached the highest value of 814.9 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1, significantly outperforming the CZA catalyst. Furthermore, the CZAL-2.5 catalyst was conducted CO2 hydrogenation reactions at different temperatures (200–300 °C, 5 MPa, 6000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, H2/CO2/Ar at 72/24/4, vol%). As depicted in Fig. S2, at 200 °C, the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity were measured at 5.0 % and 89.4 % respectively. Increasing the reaction temperature from 220 °C to 300 °C resulted in a rise in CO2 conversion from 10.4 % to 24.1 %, accompanied by a decrease in methanol selectivity from 81.6 % to 62.3 %. This is because high temperature leads to more RWGS side reactions. The highest STY of 361.9 gMeOH Kgcat −1 h−1 was achieved at a reaction temperature of 260 °C. Meanwhile, the CZAL-2.5 catalyst is tested at various pressures from 1 to 7 MPa (260 °C, 6000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, H2/CO2/Ar at 72/24/4, vol%, Fig. S3). At a pressure of 1 MPa, the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity were 16.3 % and 53.4 %, respectively. Increasing the pressure from 2 MPa to 7 MPa resulted in an increase in both the CO2 conversion from 17.8 % to 25.0 % and methanol selectivity from 60.0 % to 81.4 %, which is ascribed to the high pressure is beneficial to entropy reduction reaction. An evaluation of catalyst durability of 100 h using CZA and CZAL-2.5 catalysts under the optimized reaction conditions (260 °C, 5 MPa, 6000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, H2/CO2/Ar at 72/24/4, vol%) is discussed in detail (Fig. 1c and d). It is worth noting that although the CO2 conversion almost remained stable within 100 h over the CZA catalyst (initial CO2 conversion of 18.8 % vs the end CO2 conversion of 17.4 %), the STY of methanol significantly decreased from 301.1 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1 to 260.4 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1. Meanwhile, the CO selectivity increased from 25.7 % to 29.0 %. It can be inferred that the decrease of STY of methanol indicates that the structure of active Cu sites is unstable during the high temperature and high-pressure reaction conditions, and more RWGS active sites appear, corresponding to sintered Cu particles. Instead, the optimized CZAL-2.5 catalyst reached 22.4 % CO2 conversion, an increase of 3.6 % compared with CZA. Interestingly, its STY of methanol is as high as 360.4 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1 without any downtrend. Such a boost and robust catalytic performance upon CZAL-2.5 of CO2 conversion, methanol productivities, and steady RWGS activity embody lanthanum species contributed to the construction of more and more robust Cu active sites. 3.2 The structure and improved Cu dispersion of the CZAL-x catalysts Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) images were used to observe the morphologies of the CZA and CZAL-x catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2 a–f, both the CZA and CZAL-x catalysts exhibited bulky structures with a rocky shape. Careful comparative analysis manifests that there is no obvious macro-structural change from CZA to CZAL-x samples. Hence, the N2 physical absorption-desorption was applied to further analyze the channel discrepancy among these samples. The sorption isotherms and pore diameter distribution of the samples are shown in Fig. 2g and h. All CZA and CZAL-x samples exhibit IV-type curves with an H3-type hysteresis loop observed in the range of 0.70 < P/P0 < 0.95, indicating the presence of mesoporosity, matched with the data of the pore distributions (Fig. 2h). Further analysis reveals that CZA has a surface area of 68.9 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 0.39 cm3 g−1 (refer to Table 1 ). Accordingly, the addition of lanthanum significantly regulates the porous structure. The CZAL-x series of samples have specific surface areas ranging from 73.9 to 95.1 m2 g−1 and pore volumes ranging from 0.42 to 0.50 cm3 g−1, respectively. The values of specific surface areas fluctuate greatly versus the small changes in the total pore volume. The pore structure is analyzed in more detail. Compared with CZA, the pore size of CZAL-1, 2.5, and 5 samples shifted down to a smaller size, indicating that the introduction of lanthanum species changed the formation process of pores, thus making a higher specific surface area of 82.7, 95.1, 93.5 m2 g−1. However, for CZAL-10, 20 samples, the introduction of excessive lanthanum species does not significantly change the pore distribution and specific surface area, which may be due to the formation of independent phase separation. Notably, the CZAL-2.5 sample shows the highest values with a surface area of 95.1 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 0.50 cm3 g−1. Generally, as the lanthanum content increases, both the BET-specific surface areas and pore volumes exhibit a volcano-shaped trend. As mentioned above, the proper introduction of lanthanum changed the material formation process, enriched the nanoporosity, and is beneficial to exposing more active structures and improving the catalytic activity. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) is carried out to identify the evolution of metallic species (Fig. 3 ). It showcases XRD patterns of calcined and pre-reduced CZA, alongside an array of CZAL-x samples. The calcined samples exhibit diffraction peaks at 35.5°, 38.7°, 48.7°, 58.3°, 61.5°, 65.8°, and 66.2°, etc., which can be attributed to the CuO grains (JCPDS 45–0937). Correspondingly, additional peaks are observed at 31.8°, 34.4°, 36.3°, and 56.6°, associated with the crystalline ZnO phase (JCPDS 36–1451). In addition, no prominent peaks indicative of Al2O3. Noticeably, there is a lack of visible lanthanum species patterns of the CZAL-1, 2.5, 5, which suggests that it is highly dispersed. The signal of LaOx phases is discerned on the calcined CZAL-10 and CZAL-20 samples, demonstrating the presence of the bulk La2O3 particles, keeping in good line with the discussion results of N2 sorption. Following pre-reduction, the samples display intensity peaks at 43.3° and 50.4°, conclusively identified as metallic Cu (JCPDS 04–0836). In detail, the size of Cu particles is estimated by the Scherrer formula, as shown in Table 2 . The results show that the doping of lanthanum plays an important role in inducing the formation of smaller Cu particles. Intriguingly, the missing LaOx diffraction signal signifies that lanthanum species still maintain high dispersibility in reduced CZAL-2.5 samples. Thus, the surface Cu dispersion is further supported by the N2O reactive frontal chromatograph analysis. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the Cu dispersion on the calcined CZA catalyst measures 17.3 %, while it reaches 20.7 % on the CZAL-2.5 catalyst, indicating that the incorporation of highly dispersed LaOx promotes the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles. What's more, Figs. 4b and S4 illustrate the CO2-TPD profiles of both the CZA and various CZAL-x samples. All samples displayed a CO2 low-temperature desorption peak at around ∼150 °C, which is ascribed to the moderate basic sites related to metal-oxygen pairs [32]. The other CO2 desorption peak at higher temperatures belongs to a strong basic site, which is related to oxygen-negative ions with low coordination [32]. Furthermore, the semi-quantitative results of the CO2 absorption capability of CZAL-x samples are 0.263 to 0.526 mmol g−1 (Fig. S4). These findings suggest that the addition of lanthanum to the CZA catalyst enhances the adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst's surface. 3.3 The changed chemical properties and structural robustness of active Cu species over the CZAL catalysts Fig. 5 illustrates the results of temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) tests. All samples exhibit two distinct peaks in the range of 150∼205 °C and 210∼240 °C, which corresponds to the reduction processes of CuO to Cu2O and Cu2O to metallic Cu, consistent with the XRD results. Moreover, the CZA sample displays the highest reduction temperatures at 204 °C and 234 °C, slightly surpassing those of the CZAL-x samples (163∼199 °C and 211∼224 °C). This phenomenon can be reasonably attributed to the enhanced dispersion of Cu nanoparticles facilitated by the addition of lanthanum. To be specific, the differentiation phenomenon can be reasonably attributed to the enhanced dispersion of Cu species (small size particles) facilitated by the highly dispersed LaOx of CZAL-1, 2.5, 5 samples, while the bulk LaOx in CZAL-10, 20 samples do not form intimate interaction with CuO species (bigger size particles). To elucidate the detailed change of electronic structure upon active Cu species modulated by highly dispersed LaOx, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out and XPS spectra for Cu and La are depicted in Figs. 6 and S5. As evident by Cu 2p and La 3d spectra, the absence of Cu2+ satellite peaks (binding energy of 940.0∼942.5 eV) signified the complete reduction from Cu2+ to Cu+ and/or Cu0 species on both the pre-reduced CZA and CZAL-2.5 samples [33]. The corresponding peaks around 850∼860 and 830–845 eV are attributed to La 3d 3/2 and La 3d 5/2, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. S5 of La 3d spectra [27,30]. Further discrimination between these species was facilitated by utilizing Cu LMM data from AES. The corresponding peaks at kinetic energies of around ∼918.30/918.49 and ∼914.76/914.71 eV are attributed to Cu0 and Cu+ species, respectively [34]. Additionally, the surface element composition of CZA and CZAL-2.5 catalyst is presented in Table R2. Compared to the CZA catalyst, more Cu species were enriched on the CZAL-2.5 catalyst surface with 5.7 % Cu0 and 11.0 % Cu+. The Cu0/Cuδ+ ratio is determined to be 0.44 for CZA which is slightly lower than 0.52 for CZAL-2.5. This discrepancy in ratios likely emanates from the introduction of Cu-LaOx through lanthanum addition to the CZA catalyst. It is indicated that the incorporation of La species enhances the Cu species content of the CZAL-2.5 catalyst, thus improving the CO2 and H2 adsorption and transformation. The structure of metal particles over the reduced catalysts is characterized by TEM (Fig. 7 ). Through the careful comparison of TEM imaging between CZA and CZAL-2.5 (Fig. 7a and b), it is found that more dispersed metal particles are formed on the metal oxide surface after lanthanum is introduced. In Fig. 7c and d, the crystal plane spacing of ∼2.08 Å and ∼2.39 Å marked by white lines belong to the (111) and (101) of metallic Cu0 and ZnOx particles, respectively. The distance between metallic Cu0 and ZnOx particles is about several nanometers, which implies that they are closely related. Combined with element mapping (Fig. 7e–j), it is indicated that the Cu, Zn, Al, and La species are uniformly distributed on the CZAL-2.5 catalyst. The compared results suggest that the addition of LaOx contributes to inhibiting the aggregation of Cu nanoparticles during the calcination and reduction process. To investigate the structural stability of active Cu+/Cu0 species, the catalyst after the reaction was characterized by XRD and TEM again. Fig. S6 shows the XRD pattern of the spent CZA and CZAL-2.5 catalysts, exhibiting the similar diffraction of metallic Cu0 and ZnO species with those of the pre-reduced catalysts. Accordingly, semi-quantitative analysis of the spent catalysts derived from XRD proved that the size of Cu particles of CZAL-2.5 (∼12.5 nm) is smaller than that of CZA (∼18.4 nm) (Table S4). Besides, TEM imaging of the spent CZA and CZAL-2.5 catalysts (Fig. 8 ) shows a very close spatial relationship has been formed in the form of Cu-ZnOx structure. Furthermore, the coke deposition on the surface of CZA and CZAL-2.5 catalysts after 100 h was also detected by TG. The weight loss of coke over the CZAL-2.5 spent catalyst after a 100 h reaction is below ∼1 %. While the weight loss of coke over CZA spent catalyst after 100 h reaction is almost 1.5 % (Fig. S7). To sum up, the introduction of appropriate lanthanum species improves the structural stability of active Cu species, resulting in excellent catalytic activity and stability. 3.4 In-situ drifts study on CO2 hydrogenation reaction To clarify the influence of the structure on the adsorbed substances, the mixed gas of CO2 and H2 was introduced into the CZA and CZAL-2.5 at 300 °C for in-situ DRIFTS spectroscopy (Fig. 9). For the CZA catalyst, there are two peaks at 1601 and 1375 cm−1, which belong to b-CO3H* and HCOO* respectively [4,35]. For the CZAL-2.5 catalyst, extra signals appeared at positions of 1511 and 1256 cm−1, which are attributed to b-CO3* and COOH* [35]. Besides, the CZAL-2.5 catalyst shows a higher intensity vibration signal (0.42) at around 1600 cm−1 than that of the CZA catalyst (0.12), which explains the reason for its better activity. Meanwhile, the overall peaks upon the CZAL-2.5 happen blue shift, indicating that La doping enhanced the chemical adsorption toward the intermediate species, which was beneficial to the specific reaction producing methanol. Finally, the capture of the above intermediates proves that the process of hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol on the surface of the CZAL-2.5 catalyst follows the formate path. 4 Conclusion In this study, lanthanum doping plays a significant impact on the classical CZA catalyst in the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. This modulation has greatly enhanced the catalytic performance of the CZAL-2.5 catalyst, the methanol space-time yield can reach up to 814.9 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1, showing promise in meeting potential application needs. In a continuous evaluation spanning 100 h of the CZAL-2.5 catalyst, performance remained stable without any deactivation, outshining the CZA catalysts. Characterization results of the catalysts show that the introduced LaOx could not only promote the dispersion of Cu active sites but also benefit the improvement of structural robustness of Cu nanoparticles. Also, the moderate basic sites are in favor of the adsorption of CO2, thus boosting the methanol STY. As a result, La-doped CZA catalysts, show obvious improvements in activity and stability. This approach may offer insights into the design of efficient Cu catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of Cu-based catalysts in the low-temperature catalytic conversion of CO2 to methanol is the focus of industrial processes. However, the metastable nature of highly dispersed Cu active sites causes it easy to sinter, which leads to the decline of activity and methanol selectivity. Herein, an approach involving the incorporation of highly dispersed La species into Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 (CZAL-x) through one-pot synthesis, benefits dispersing and stabilizing Cu0/Cu+ active sites. Consequently, a CO2 conversion reaches 22.4 % with a 75.0 % methanol selectivity of the optimizing CZAL-2.5 catalyst in a stable reaction for 100 h. When the space velocity is 16,000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, the space-time yield of methanol reached the highest value of 814.9 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1, significantly outperforming the CZA catalyst. Systematic characterizations reveal the introduction of LaOx enhanced the interaction between Cu active sites and carrier, which effectively improved the sintering resistance of copper nanoparticles.
